Actually, the major reason for the the terminator to not seem to fit in direction is that the plane of the ecliptic (lets pretend for a moment the moon orbiting in the plane of the ecliptic) is for most latitudes not on the horizon but makes a sine curve on the visible sky. The sun and the moon stay in this plane (again: moon very close but not perfect) and the terminator is always at a right angle to this plane.

Place a number of footballs spread over the ground in front of where you can observe both the moon and sun prior to taking a photograph and a few on top of other objects also in the photo. Then, If possible place one on top a pole so the football is coincident with the moon when viewed from the camera.
Next take the photo and you will see that you can draw a straight line from each football perpendicular to the football's terminator and you will see that it projects all the way back to the sun including the one that is coincident with the moon. So why is the moon a special case?

Stretch a string in your field of vision so the string intersects both the moon and the sun. You will find it perpendicular to the moon terminator.
Now put your eye directly in the center of a hula hoop and look at the ring from the inside, so you can see no curve to it. Now intersect the sun and moon on that ring. You will see it perpendicular to the moon terminator. Your string could be tied to the hula hoop at the points where it crosses the moon and sun.
Now imagine another giant hula hoop around your first one, aligned with it, hidden behind it, a mile in diameter. It will still look like a straight line no matter which direction you look.
Take the sun knot off the string on your small hula hoop, and tie it to the big hula hoop a mile away. Still perpendicular to the moon terminator, but now you see a better example of why the terminator has a certain curve to it, being lit from further behind the moon a mile away or from the side, or even from behind your own head, lighting up a full moon.

Here's a test. Take your cell phone. Still on standby. Screen not actually even responsive. Stare at it for a moment. And then close both eyes and with your thumb start scrolling across the blank screen. How many of you notice you can't physically stop your eyeballs from scrolling along with the blank screen and eyelids closed, those eyeballs keep going even when the only input is the familiar feeling of your thumb scraping against the glass screen.

Surprised you never mentioned stereovision having some bit to do with it. You're visualizing the world using two cameras a few inches apart just by existing and seeing things, unless you're blind in one eye. So between a subject in frame and your two eyeballs you're drawing straight line triangles even with no other clues simply because there are two eyeballs and one test subject. Move the test subject closer and further and the angle of this triangle between the two eyeballs change. Ask someone who's always been blind in one eye how they're affected differently. Because they are affected differently. Depth perception suddenly requires much more massive amount of cognitive capability. Imagine trying to swing a hammer to hit a nail when you've only ever had one working eyeball and you've never used a hammer before. It is NOT the same as just closing one eye.

the use of the dolly-zoom effect in Alfred Hitchcock's 1958 movie "Vertigo" -
or the only person - watching (or making) this video - who even knows about it ?!?

in any event - and just for the record -
this effect has long been KNOWN as the "Vertigo" effect -
due to its pivotal use in said movie -
to depict the terrifying sensation experienced - both commonly -
and in exaggerated form by the movie's protagonist -
when looking straight down from a deadly height.

The reason we don't see the line being tilted one way or the other is because the camera's perspective is relative to the horizon to the line at the top. this means we would have to tilt our head to the horizon of the line. Then we will see the tilt in the line.

I have always maintained to people who won't try gliding for that reason that you don't see the "height" like you would off the side of a building; because your eye doesn't have the converging in front of it that gives your brain the ability to calculate distance. I saw this “moon-pointer” illusion myself years ago and didn't look into it until I saw something from some flat Earth debunker.
.

This is certainly a 3D, 2D, projection, perspective, vanishing point, perception problem.
I do understand perspective and vanishing point and I “get it”, but the following demo allows anyone to wave an arm around and see what is happening pretty quickly.
.
There is a very simple demo that anyone can actually experience with that wall-ceiling line that can make this immediately obvious to anyone.
.
Your rotating camera gets close to the essence, but this demo can really cement it in people’s minds.
..
The setup.
Stand about 2-3 feet away but directly facing a long wall; the longer the wall the better – at one end of a hallway with your shoulder touching the end of the hall can be very good. You must have a pretty clear view of the ceiling-wall joint. This is now a horizontal line that is about 4 feet above you and at 45 degrees above level. It is clearly straight and completely horizontal.
.
Now extend a straight, stiff arm out and up to point at the nearest point of the joint in a nazi-like salute with a flat palm downward so the thumb-pinky hand sort of mimics the line.

*Step One to see true the geometry. *
Without turning your body, Swing your stiff arm and head to one side to follow that line and try to continue that pointing out to the vanishing point. Your arm will be horizontal to your side as will be your gaze. The vanishing point is at your private, local horizon…always. This clearly mimics you head-in-sphere diagram.
.
Step two to grasp the illusion.
Starting at the original nazi-like salute, hold your shoulder joint rigid, pointing upward, but now rotate your whole, STIFF body and arm (shoulder joint locked in position). You are pointing way above the vanishing point! This is what your brain told you to believe.
.
This all works because the moon is up at an angle and the sun is really far away; essentially “at” the vanishing point.
.
Carrying this to the extreme would start with the moon over-head.
Although flat Earthers don’t “do” geometry, this is one of the proofs that the sun is far away.
Regards, Steve

When I was a kid I flew commercial a lot as an unattended minor. I remember looking out the window and wondering why the airplane seemed to be slowing down the higher we got, and at cruise seemed to just be hanging there, hardly moving. I knew there was an optical effect at play, but nobody was able to explain it (or even understand my question, often)...the epiphany came when I was staring out the window with the seat leaned back so that the rear of the window opening was cutting into my view. Then I realized that if I looked down, and spotted ground features I could identify and approximate the size of, I could watch them disappear right at the rear edge of the window, and imagine myself on the ground, moving that fast, like in a really fast car....finally I had the visual sensation of the speed involved. Distance from the ground plays hell with out perception of ground speed, even on a smaller scale. There is actually a formula that tells how many mph your perception is off according to how many feet above the ground you are. But I don't remember it. But if you ever get to ride in a big rig, it will be one of the first things you notice, when you get on the highway it will seem like you're going 40-45 mph but you're keeping up with traffic, and when you look you see you are doing 65-70 mph. Just being seated in a seat that's 6 feet off the ground so your eyes are 9 feet up or so knocks a good 20-25 mph off your normal car-based visual perception of speed, and you have to adjust to it. Then, when you DRIVE the truck for a month at a time, as I did, there's always a brief period of feeling like you're really flying at regular speeds when you go home and drive a regular vehicle again. Neat stuff.

I have a bit of a disagreement with the camera experiment. The Moon terminator illusion happens even when the Moon and the Sun are both in our field of view. The line between the wall and the ceiling is always a straight line even on the camera screen across the entire field of view. Only when the field of view changes does the line's slope change. But that's now a different situation from the Moon terminator situation where the whole thing sits in our field of view. I would back up what I just said by insisting that if you take a picture containing both the Sun and the Moon, the illusion still appears, whereas the ceiling's edge is straight. I'm a huge fan of this channel, the few things I happen to know about are explained extremely accurately, much better than I ever could, but I disagree with the validity of the camera explanation and I'd love it if sb could give me their view.

I love your stuff, but unfortunately, In this video, you use the term "foreshorten" incorrectly. To foreshorten something is to make it appear to have less depth than it actually does. The apparent depth of, say, a cube is less when photographed with a telephoto lens than it is when photographed with a wide-angle lens (assuming the front surface of the cube is the same apparent size in both photographs). This is because the zoom lens makes the back-surface of the cube look almost as big as the front surface, and it's the difference in size between the two which our brains take as a depth cue for the cube.

Long lenses foreshorten objects.

The dolly-zoom effect is a vivid illustration of foreshortening. When far away and zoomed in, the entire scene is foreshortened. When close up and zoomed out, the reverse is true.

As to why the "child-like" perspective was popular in art in medieval times, an important feature of pre-Renaissance painting was that size of subjects were often indicators of importance and reputation. A powerful figure, like the ruler or a religious leader, would be depicted larger than less important figures within the same painting or work of art, completely disregarding the demands of mathematical perspective. You could also observe this with soldiers in terms of their ranks in war depictions. Uncoincidentally, the progressive ideas that developed alongside Renaissance, such as humanism and the decentralization of power, went hand in hand with the shift of perspective in art.

You almost touched on a question I've had for a long time.  It seems to me that classic Linear Perspective is an approximation.  The line segments look like the straighter portions of hyperbolas to me, and I think the panning of cameras proves that.  I believe that the subtle weirdness and fakeness of a linear perspective drawing could be corrected by introducing hyperbolic curvature.  I think a fish eye lens shows this effect by widening the field of view.  I also wonder if the Ancient Greek concept of Entasis, and other curvatures applied to their artecture, derive from this hyperbolic hypothesis.  Perhaps a follow-up to this video?

6:10  fantastic illustration of how our brains interpret apparent perspective.   Many tines the "flat Earth" idiots look at the Sun and Moon in the sky and claim the lit part of the moon is wrong.  For instance with the Moon at a 10 o'clock position and the Sun at the 4 o'clock position.  With these positions the Moon is at "First Quarter", but the lit portion does not appear to point back at the Sun. Their "conclusion is that the Moon is "self illuminating".  However the Sun, of course IS lighting the Moon, and their three dimensional perception is poor.  At 6 pm this same Moon will overhead(toward the South) and still be half lit and the Sun will be setting.  It is easier to visualize the half moon and half-Earth lining up at that point.

3:13 Frustum edges of the camera are parallel with the edges of the room, then as the camera yaws to face the corner this is no longer the case. However a straight line is always shown as the camera moves so hence it's a straight line in space. Though on a 'fish eye' lens this might not be the case, but this is a narrow FOV camera. This makes me wonder, what kind of lens was used to film the sun and moon together?

1:35 When equal length lines (door edges in this case) are the same distance from the camera they take up the same 'angular distance', and larger 'angular distance' when closer. I don't think it's anything more complicated than that.

I've found the use of psychedelics deconstructs much of your perception, visual and otherwise, removing what Michael calls post-sensation processing. This is the reason everything seems to be warped while under the influence, since your brain stops seeing the line between the ceiling and the wall as a straight one, but instead sees it as your eyes sense it, a collection of nonparallel lines that connect into a sort of wavy curve. This is only one example that came to mind during this video but psychedelics affect many other areas of the brain as well.

I think psychedelics are great tools for the research of human perception, since many of the systems that go into it are only apparent when disrupted. The post-sensation processing is a bit like special effects in movies. When done right, you don't even notice it, so you only begin to appreciate it when you find out exactly how much needs to happen for you to have your normal perception of reality.

Yeah, it's cool that what we see is intentionally skewed so we can understand it better. I actually did my senior project in college on figuring out algorithms for displaying 3D images, and I learned a lot of cool things from it. For instance, think about this: you think your vision is just a flat rectangle, like a screen, but in reality you're seeing in a wide angle. Thus, when you take something on your right, and something on your left, and move them away from yourself along the angle you're seeing them from, they won't actually appear to get any further away from each other, only you know they are. I can't even bring myself to perceive this, but after running the numbers I know it's true.
A version of this is used in Islamic prayer. When facing Mecca from much of North America, the faithful must actually face northeast, instead of east as a map would dictate.

If medieval artists' "poor" use of perspective was intentional and calculated, wouldn't the paintings of less skilled artists of the time look more realistic? Do they? I have no data but I suspect not, which leaves me unsatisfied with the claim that it was deliberate.

The "tricks" to make art more realistic are tools of the artist, and tools are technology, and technology is invented at some point and then disseminated. It seems more probable to me that the technology of accounting for perspective in art was simply not widespread, and also thus not an expectation of art-viewers of the period. We live in a modern world where we expect movie SFX to be 100% photo realistic or we say they look "bad". But for 100 years people were impressed with a progression of movie effects that were far from photo realism. We didn't expect photo realism until the tech was there to give us a taste of it. Think of live theater where a special effect could be a "comet" on a stick movies by a stagehand. No one in the audience is tricked to think "OMG THERE'S A COMET IN THE THEATER", but it's a representation of a comet for the sake of the story, and people get the message. We no longer say "wow that looks way better than Le Voyage Dans la Lun", we say "ugh I can tell it's not real". Instead of saying "wow that painting looks way better than the generations preceding it", we say "ugh it's not even close to as real as a photograph".

Artistic representations of things are just symbolic representations of those things to get the idea into the viewers head. A drawing of a cat is a (simple symbol for a cat). People got the message that the ball on a stick in the theater was supposed to represent a comet, and they were fine with that. Pre-renaissanse artists probably just did not consider perspective or spend time worrying about it, they were probably much more focused on the simple inclusion of the object-representations they wanted to include in the piece. This is a matter of technology and priorities, but does not mean they were stupid as 5 year olds, or that they were deliberately Picasso-ing their work.

Not sure, but I think this is at least related: on a day when the sun and moon are both in the sky and you are able to stand in the sunlight while viewing the moon, take something like a tennis ball and hold it out at arm's length so that it covers the moon.  You will notice that the shadow on the ball matches the shadow on the moon.  This will be particularly interesting if the moon terminator illusion is in effect and it probably will be.  When I do this, and I realize that the sun's light is hitting the moon at virtually the same angle as the sun hitting the earth, this helps to dispel the illusion.  The face of the sun is close to a million miles across (860,000 miles roughly?), and the moon is only about 240,000 miles from earth.  The sun washes the earth-moon system with light; it isn't a pinpoint in space producing any kind of noticeable angle.  If I could stand on the spot on the moon corresponding to the spot I occupy on earth, the sun would be in virtually the same position in the sky relative to me.  This tennis ball idea isn't original with me, but I have no recollection when/how I learned it.

Parallax is best demonstrated in Fallout 3/Skyrim, where you move side to side to match up your objective marker with something in sight, or to see how close you are.

A lot of this explains why 3D glasses work. Things that are further apart from each other in the two images are further apart because they are closer to the camera - so when each eye sees each image, they then appear closer to you.

In a planar camera projection, all straight lines remain straight. What you are seeing is a result of using a wide angle lens with barrel distortion, which I don't think you touched on in 11-plus minutes of video.

You could start here: https://photographylife.com/what-is-distortion

I found out an interesting fact that kind of ties in with the star field at 8:15. In the UK we have a broken white line in the middle of the roads, I always just thought 'that's just how they are''

However, the broken line is spaced widely apart when on a long straight road, but when you approach any kind of hazard, say a corner or something, the broken line becomes more bunched up, to make you subconsciously think that you're going fast, too fast in fact.

It's not parallax, but still fools the brain.

The information regarding perspective was certainly known to (western) roman painters and 2d artists.  We know this from the bits of surviving murals.  This information was lost after the fall of the Roman empire, however, and was not preserved in Byzantine education.  It's difficult to say whether changing values meant that byzantine art broke the rules of perspective- they were likely never educated in the rules to begin with.

The "pre-Renaissance paintings" Michael references are actually not "paintings", they're called icons. Icons are "teaching pictures" first, and "art pieces" second. Icons differ from paintings in that: 1. There isn't a vanishing point, instead the perspective opens to the viewer to reveal the focal point, Jesus Christ (the Guy with the golden halo) and 2. Icons are created in the reverse form of paintings, in that when making an icon you start with your dark colors and work towards the lighter colors. The two icons, one at 9:20 and the other at 9:45, both depict times where Jesus heals a paralytic. Video was cool other than that; I just want Michael to do his research :)

Great video!  I've never seen the terminator illusion, and hadn't heard about it until this video.  Perhaps that is due to an (IMO) adequate understanding of 3D (spacial) geometry, and/or greater than usual observation of the sky while growing up.

Something I realized a while back:

The plane formed by an object's terminator (single light source) will always be a plane that is perpendicular to the line from the light source to the object, and a person's viewing angle of the object has no bearing on this - only on the perceived ratio of illuminated to unlit surface.

If a person were to look at a crescent/quarter/gibbous Moon and mentally draw a visually straight line connecting the two outermost visible points of the terminator, that line will always be perpendicular to the line from the Sun to the Moon (and visa-versa).

The reason birds like pigeons bob their heads as they walk is because they have brains which cannot process parallax. They would be confused by things appearing to slide past one another. Instead, they hold their head in the same spot while their body moves forward, then quickly jerk it forward to a new position, seeing the world in a series of snapshots.

10:14 - Interesting thing about that painting on the left. It actually uses reverse perspective projection. That is it puts the "horizon" behind the viewer, rather than in front of the viewer. For example, look at the stool, the lines on the edges of it angle inwards toward the viewer making things in the foreground smaller and things in the background bigger rather than smaller things at the back and bigger things at the front. Apparently it was a somewhat popular style with bizantin paintings.

Another interesting thing with reverse perspective projection is that if you were to look at the front of a cube head on, you would be able to see the top, bottom, left and right side of the cube in addition to the front of it rather than just the front of it because things further away are larger than things that are closer in this perspective.

This effect can actually be seen in the back of the chair too. If you look at it the chair appears to "bend"  or "curve" very slightly when compared with the front of the chair despite being drawn with visibly straight lines. This is our brain trying to extract depth information form an image using foreshortening and being given conflicting data.

I REALLLLY wish Michael would have covered this effect with mirrors.  No matter how close or far away from a mirror you are, your image is ALWAYS the exact same size.  Don't believe me?

Stand as close to the mirror as possible and trace the outline of your head with lipstick or something similar.  Then back up while keeping your head perfectly center of the outline.  No matter how far back you go your head will still fit inside the outline perfectly.

HOWEVER!  If someone stands right in front of the mirror and stays there while you back up, your image will shrink from THEIR perspective.

WWHHYYYEEE???  Why don't the angle's change for you as you observe your own image?

I went to Art and Design school.. and this was my favorite subject! the weird thing was that a lot of my friends were just baffled by it..practically 80% of the class struggled to understand foreshortening and perspective drawing. A couple of years later.. the same teacher(with a new batch of students) came up with a novel way to make them understand it. Instead of paper or canvas on an easel, she made them all use sheets of glass on easels!! so they could see through their drawing medium and "trace" perspective from life. In a few minutes they all got it! (ok this was before we all had computers and digital cameras to play with)
Perspective is always key.

More specifically, as we learned from Einstein, speed has a measurable effect on our perception of time... What most people also are unaware of is that everything you see is inverted in the back of your eye. But the human brain is able to help us see it oriented in the right direction. If you wear a pair of glasses that inverts everything, you'll have a hard time walking and reading for a few weeks, but after that, your brain will have adapted to it and will think it's normal. Taking off the glasses after a few weeks and you will have a hard time going back to normal way you see.

To understand why pre-renaissance paintings used that kind of perspective, you have to understand a key difference in the way the representation was conceived. In renaissance the key was the individual (thus the humanism), so the perspective came from a human, things should look as real as humans sees them ( thus rationalism or empiricism), while the key for the perspective of medieval art was the concept of Fideism, where ideas and representations of those were determined by the religious beliefs (thus Theologism).

Another example can be seen in Ancient Egypt art, Pharaohs were portrayed as huge compared to it's peers, this was done because Pharaohs were more in touch with God (which were portrayed even bigger), priests were in the midway, and the people were portrayed in regular size.

How to Make Fried Chicken :
Heat grill for indirect grilling: Light one side of grill, leaving other side unlit. Close lid; heat grill to 375ºF.
Mix first 5 ingredients; rub onto chicken.
Open beer can; discard half the beer. Place can on work surface; lower chicken over can, inserting can into tail end of chicken. Stand chicken on grate over unlit area, using the legs to help the chicken stand upright; cover. (Can should remain in chicken on grill.)
Grill chicken 1 hour; brush with 1/4 cup sauce. Grill, uncovered, 15 min. or until chicken is done (165ºF), monitoring for consistent grill temperature and brushing chicken frequently with remaining sauce. Remove from grill; cover loosely with foil. Let stand 10 min. before removing chicken from can and carving chicken. Discard any beer remaining in can.

He's wrong about the renaissance though. The art did not change because style changed it changed because of the invention of the camera. It's a secret now widely known that artisans of the time used a lens and a dark room to project an image on wall, would then outline the perspective before removing the canvas to paint it. Some examples of this process are proven by the way the size of canvas changed and became uniform among multilple artists because of the way the lens would focus and other examples include the shroud of Turin where you see the image of Jesus on a sheet, the body being in one focus and the head in another, it also explains why there was no pigment found on the sheet because the artist 'burned' the image into the sheet using a process that was reinvented centuries later, the camera.

When analyzing meteorological satellite imagery, the effects of foreshortening and the terminator effect from day to night are things you notice all the time. Having a Mercator and equidistant style gridded image looping of geostationary satellite imagery can help overcome extrapolation errors when watching fronts, shear lines, storms, tropical cyclones etc.

On infrared imagery contamination is another common error that must be accounted for.

Hello Michael and fellow VSauce watchers! I have a question which I think you could make a pretty interesting video out of.

We know a black hole is formed when a star 20 or more solar masses exhausts its fuel and collapses in on itself, creating a super nova and sometimes a black hole; an object with a gravitational pull so strong not even light can escape.

We also know that, theoretically, anything could become a black hole. If the earth was compacted into the size of a marble, it would become a black hole. Furthermore, if I was compacted into the size of an atom, I too could become a black hole.

So my question is this; if I were to become a black hole right now, what effect would that have, both immediately and over time, on the earth, the solar system, the milky way galaxy and ultimately the entire universe?

Forgive me if my facts are incorrect; I'm not a scientist, just a 12th grade student who likes his science.

If you look at Video Games, some of those those that are in 3D environments, you can see what is a "fish lends" effect, where the sides of the screen look warped when you turn side-to-side (one of the biggest offenders of this is the FNAF series). The room is static, but you see the angles of the room bend as the camera pans side to side. Minecraft as well has this, but not in nearly as noticeable a way. The example of the camera pointed at the ceiling is perhaps the best way to explain why this happens in many of these video games.

That's how Sir Peter Jackson filmed The Hobbit/The Lord of the Rings when all the actors were the same size but he wanted them to look different

Perspective is one of my favourite things to learn about, but it's hard, because the word "perspective" is mostly used non-literally to mean a "view on a state of affairs", making finding writing on optical perspective hard to find. The most interesting to me is "reverse perspective", where you are AT the vanishing point and things where you are are infinitely small and get bigger the further they are in the background (though, near, small objects still block the view of far away ones). This can be created optically for small fields of view, but if you search "true reverse perspective", some guy made a computer animation of what an entire scene would look like with these perspective rules.

Which leads me to wonder what life would be like in this perspective, and what would need to change about us or the world to see like that. It gets quite intuitive if you dwell long enough in this perspective, and it allows you to see more of an object, often allowing a view of the front and both sides of a cube in front of you due to the flared-out nature of everything. Inbetween reverse and normal perspective, is isometric perspective, where the vanishing point is infinitely far away and thus there is no forshortening and lines never appear to converge (as used in early tile-based 3D computer games).

There's also curvilinear perspective which can show a view of looking both forwards and backwards at the same time. Amazing stuff :)

what you said about perspective isnt exactly true. The problem is the framing. The way we view information is that if one of us know it then everyone on Earth knows it in some way because our information networks and ability to acquire information permit such things, but the reality is that that is a recent phenomena. So it may be the case that some artist in egypt 5000 years ago understood perspective better than we do today while everyone else in that same city understood it no better than a child. Likewise, you're ignoring the skill it takes to be a draftsman/artist as well as that the Renaisance was a time when we were relearning things that were known in the ancient world and that artists and scientists, unlike today, learned more than just their craft. Instead they learned many crafts and fields that allowed them to understand these things where as previous to that most did not.

It's nice to know that perspective in art was understood far before the Middle Ages; I was under the impression that was a renaissance invention. I suppose it makes sense though: in medieval art, the focus was on drawing events and people, they wanted to make sure faces and objects were recognized first and foremost; the 'icons' in Byzantium are quite famous, and they were very much about drawing faces and such, so it makes sense to go for the more 'flat' art style.

some of these illusions occur because of the changing degree of the FOV (ie 90 degree fov allows for more surrounding visual info plotted 2 dimensionally, while a 60 degree is more focused and closer to a true orthographic view.) Lens FOV is very important in film and art for creating convincing images and its significance is unfortunately forgone by many amateur artists, which is why studying and caring about these kinds of things is so important for making creatively and functionally informed pieces of artwork. great video michael.

I'm surprised he didn't mention the "Moon Illusion" which is the illusion that the moon (or the sun or other celestial bodies) appear to be larger or closer when they are nearer to the horizon. Of course, the moon isn't getting any bigger or smaller, and any changes in the distance between the moon and the eye are so (relatively) negligible, no difference should be noticeable. It--and I'm very much simplifying this--is actually all down to the way the brain is perceiving the apparent size of the object, making it appear larger when near the horizon (and thus closer to a frame of reference)... similar to Michael's example of the cars on the road. In reality, the moon is actually ever so slightly SMALLER (relative to your visual field) in the vertical axis when nearer the horizon than it is otherwise due to atmospheric lensing! Neat!

I'm not so sure that pre-Renaissance artists painted in an abstract manner simply because they preferred the style. Perspective was a 'thought technology' that had to be worked out through reason and experimentation and then taught to later generations.

Like other technologies, once it was understood the idea could be developed and built upon. Also like other technologies, we often struggle to realise how innovative and revolutionary seemingly simple advances actually were.

That's not to say that Medieval art was child-like, just that they were working with different techniques and advancing in different ways. The art and craft of some art from earlier eras may indeed have been 'ahead' of later art in some ways, but they still simply didn't know what they didn't know.

If you didn't teach a child perspective and then when they reached adulthood you asked them to draw scenes that required that understanding, I doubt they could figure out how everything should look, unless they happened to be as great as Da Vinci was.

Why does this video seem like it's trying really hard to disprove flat earth theory, without actually coming out and saying that?

The moon terminator shadow was visible this past memorial day, where at 3 pm the moon was about the same angle in the sky opposite the sun. But appeared to be lit from the wrong angle. The moon was clearly out of the earth's shadow because it was high in the sky at the same time the sun was up. If the moon is 237k miles away from us, and the sun 92 million miles from us, then the sun's rays would illuminate the moon fully... Right?

Unless they are actually closer then we are told.

Not that I fully buy that theory... Because it is just a theory. But it does have some merits. But when I saw the moon and the sun up at the same time last week and noticed the shadow thing, and thought about their distances from us, I began to scratch my head as to how this can be.

Picture our planet the moon and the sun. If the sun represents an omnidirectional flashlight orb, and the moon a reflector orb, and we are on an orbit in roughly the same plane. If the moon is above us and clearly visible some 237k miles away, then the flashlight sun's rays should not be influenced by the earth in the surface of the moon. It's June right now... Do you know how high in the sky the sun is at 3pm? It's just past straight up. No where near the horizon.

I draw it out on paper, and it just does not make sense. And the moon's position (third quarter) is verifiable on Memorial day weekend. I just can't buy the shadow thing if the sun's light rays are straight coming at us from 92 million miles away.
